svg.text: Signal strength: A=35%, B=52%, C=48% → Eliminate Group A (lowest signal)
Note: Noisy signals can make the true target ★ appear in the LOWEST-scoring group!
Signal strength: X=58%, Y=41%, Z=55% → Eliminate Group Y (lowest signal) — but ★ was in Y!
Pick best from final 3 (highest noisy score) → Guess = 15
✗ FAILED! True target ★ was at 25 (removed by noisy elimination)
First attempt used noisy signals → made wrong eliminations
The algorithm samples neighbors using the SAME noisy evaluator. No access to the true answer!
This directional feedback is FREE INFORMATION that focuses our second attempt!
Corrected Search Region: [guess .. guess + radius] — we hope the target is in here
Round 1 (Second Attempt): candidates in corrected window
After additional elimination: choose best remaining candidate
Second attempt found a match that passes validation!
Quaylyn's Law states: "Reversible steps are safer than irreversible steps"
✓ First attempt: Aggressive elimination with uncertain signals → may fail
✓ Second attempt: Sample neighbors to infer direction, re-search focused region
Tested across 1000 trials × 12 configurations = 12,000 total tests (direction inferred by sampling, not cheating)
